page.lettertext:
fol.71r
May it please yo
r
good L. having had some speech w
th
S
r
Francis Vere
who hath
furnished unto me what hath passed at the campe in his dealing w
th
Count
Maurice
I see no other hope of obtaining that demaund w
ch
he maketh for hir
Ma
ty
then I have formerly declared, For syth yt was never but privately
resolved, and onely w
th
c
o
dition, yf hir
Ma
ty
would assiste them, they will
make no other answere but privately againe and
sist in that condition w
th
owt
the w
ch
they have no meanes to repasse that exployt, The place to
be assieged is so deere unto thennemy as in every mans opinion he will
straine to relieve it w
th
his uttermost power, And how this contrey wilbe
hable to maintayne such a siege boath by land and by water, neyther
having a retraict, nor force sufficient to attend the enemy, I know yo
r
L. doth consyder. Were yt so, that a niew levy of 2000 men woulde serve
their turne I should hope by good inducement they might be w
o
ne, thereunto
But they doe make their full account that w
th
a lesser army then 10
or 12 thousand footmen c
o
plete, and 2 or 3 thousand horsemen, whereto I
am assured they have not at this p
nt
above 6000 foote and 1500 horse, they
must never undertake yt. It ys not meete I shoulde p
r
sume
to move hir Highnes to doo somwhat for the advancement of this action, bycause
I know yt ys c
o
sydered, whatsoever can by sayd, both for the bennefytt of
hir contrey, and for the annoyance of thennemy. But I am certainly
swaded that yf the place be obtayned through hir Highnes assistance
the states may be drawen to such a reasonable treaty, as they will eyther
c
o
discend to a p
nt
remboursment of all hir charges up
o
the taking of
the same, or deliver to hir hand
the possession of the place. I know not
whither hir Hig
h
be advertised throughly of the revenue that ys yeelded
of the villages and townes that are of that territory. But I have
verie good intelligence, and such as I thinck I may boldly write for
certaine, that heretofore in time of peace the contribution browght
in to the gouvernor of
t
towne hath amounted every month to 10000
pownd
ster
l
w
ch
so
m
e at this p
nt
ys supposed to be greater, besyd
a furder good yt would bryng unto hir Ma
ty
. That there should
not in
Ostende
anie garrison be needfull, but the towne to be
demantelled, or at least so small a nombre, as, seeing yt ys supposed
that 800 foote and 100 horse will suffice to garde thother, hir Ma
tye
[s]
yeerly charges would not growe to be much greater then they are
at this p
nt
, Howsoever this attempte shall goe forward er
otherwise. I doo think S
r
Francis Vere shall obtaine an English
regyment, to be payd by this contrey yf her Hi
g
will
mitt yt
and I hope yt will be moved in the next assembly of the
States w
ch
may be paradventure about 15 dayes hence.
fol.71v
I will not trouble you w
th
relating what we heare of their
ce[edings]
t
are before
Geertrudenberghe,
for that S
r
Francis being there [can deliver]
yt more directlie, but all occurrences agree that thennemy [er be long,]
will com forward to their ayde. Some thinck ther will in[devor]
to diverte us fr
o
that enterpryse, by planting a siedge to som[e towne]
in this contrey for w
ch
the Magistrate of
Breda,
Bergh[en op]
Zome
,
Tertoll,
Steenberghe,
have wrytten earnestlie hither [for]
warlicke
visions.
S
r
Edward Norreys
doth advertise that [by letters]
intercepted and prisoners lately taken he ys perfectly inform[ed that]
the dessinge of thennemy ys all upo Oostende; whereup
o
he [doth]
require to be supplyed of divers want
, But forasmuch as th[ose of]
Zeeland
doo signify nothing of yt, nor no bruite ys com of yt fr
o
[any]
other place, they make light of yt here, assuring themselves [that]
althoughe the ennemy should intende yt, yet the towne in all [occasions]
may be easely succoured. Howbeyt to satisfye S
r
Edward No[rreys]
I have procured an order for him, whereby he shalbe furnished [of all]
that shalbe needfull. This day we have advertisment th[at a]
pidgeon of the ennemy w
ch
was sent from Boisleduc to Ge[rtru-]
denbergh w
th
a l
re
of incouragement and promis of reliefe [was taken]
by o
r
people. The l
re
was in cipher but p
nt
lie deciphe[red, and]
an other l
re
written w
th
the very same cipher w
ch
was f[astened]
to the pigeon and sent into the towne. Theffect of yt was [to will]
them to signifye, by making of two fyres at a certaine ho[ure in]
the night yf they were
not
in state to hold owt but 14 dayes long[er]
before w
ch
tyme they did not dowbt but to worck their [deliverance]
but we knowe not yet here yf the fyres were so made a t[he]
time assigned, Out of
frize
we understand, that C[ount William]
and
e ennemy mett both abowt one time, and at the pa[ssage]
where the Count did minde to erecte his forte, where [both their]
armyes were ranged in order of battaile and so continued tog[ether]
a good
t of the day. But thennemy would doo nothing havin[g taken]
by p
r
vention the narrowest
t of the passage w
ch
was [fyttest for a]
forte. Neverthelesse the Count doth proceede in the building of [an other]
in a place theare adjoining, by w
ch
he hopeth that Groeningh[en shall be]
be greately distressed. Heere ys
Coronel Stewart
[come]
lately owt of
Scotland
in message, fr
o
the
K
: of whose instruc[tions]
here inclosed I have sent you a copye. It ys interpretted here [.]
that all thother articles excepting the laste, as towching his
ti-
ular, and that w
ch
ys owing fr
o
the
States
unto him are but
matters of c
o
plement, and purposely devised to grace his com
i
g hither
fol.72r
This
Councell of Estate
hath taken a resolution to deprive
e
S
r
Thomas
Morgan
of his gouvernment in berghen up
o
divers p
r
tences.
First for that hir Ma
ty
had drawen hir subject
fr
o
thence, they were
sure that their soldiours would not obey him. Secondly that he caryed
himselfe very ill in the tyme of his gouvernment to the p
r
judice of
the State. And thirdly they woulde
th
no longer have a gouverno
r
there, but as they doo in other places c
o
mytt the charge to the eldest
Cap
n
. And chainge as they see cause I have opposed against them
as much as ys possible, alledging for the Gouverno
r
that he ys
one of the auncientest soldiours that hath served this contrey, that
he was gon into his contrey, w
th
their leave and good lyking, that
their soulgiars have bin ruled verie willingly by him, that he never
yet refused to com to answere anie matter wherew
th
they coulde
charge him, that to condempne him in his absence, w
th
owt citing
him first yt had no forme of any equity. that yf could not be but
taken verie evill by hir Ma
ty
, and be offensive to all that knewe
yt, w
th
other speeches to lyke purpose, what my pleading will p
r
vaile
I cannot certainly say, bycause the matter may happen to be resumed
by them, but knowing as I doo their implacable humo
r
whersoever
yt takes a pitche, I am owt of all hope to their better
ceeding
And besyd
I may conjecture by sundry speciall tokens, that Co.
Maurice underhand hath bin the author of this course, and dothe
purpose ere be longe, to place a favorite of his owne.
And so
I take my humble leave fr
o
the Haegh the 18 Ap
r
1593.
